It might have been better to use a top-fermenting yeast, which would 1) prevent the yeast from sinking into the cellulose at the bottom, and 2) be more efficient at such a high temperature, since the optimal temperature for top-fermenting yeast about 30°C whereas for bottom-fermenting yeast it's 5-10°C.

You could have used a hydrometer to measure the the amount of available sugar, and then measure it later on to work out the % alcohol. There's more to it than that but that's how you work out what % to expect and when it's finished fermenting. Also brewers yeast typically work in the 15-25c range, above 30 is too high and you'll have inefficient fermentation with off-flavours from the stressed yeast, or even kill the fermentation. The fact that you put in the oven and the fermentation stopped sounds like you killed your yeast. You had very little sedimentation as well, which is another sign that fermentation ended early.

Also you probably have cancer now from the drain cleaner and bleach form the toilet paper along with other additives.

Oh as soon as the pandemic started, I absolutely bought a still and started fermenting moonshine. I made a whole bunch of it and I used the heads and tails to make hand sanitizer whilst I naturally drank the good part. While it was distilling, I collected small glasses with no more than a shot or two in them so I could compare them later and determine while ones had the good alcohol in them and which ones were the heads and tails.

Most of the time, making moonshine is illegal because too many people don't know what they're doing and set shit on fire. Since I had taken three years of college chemistry and sat there watching for the entire three hours that it took me to distill out the alcohol from a couple of gallons of fermented corn, I did not encounter any problems. I even started to get a feel for how to do it but then I got terribly sick with COVID-19 and haven't made any since then. This video has inspired me to start back up again, especially since I have all the ingredients to do so.

As a recreational homebrewer (beers and ciders) I was thrilled by your chemist's take on the fermentation step. I noticed you used a hydrometer to measure the alcohol content of the distilled spirits; I've never distilled anything but I use a hydrometer to measure the alcohol content post-fermentation.

To do that, you measure the specific gravity of the liquid before and after fermentation. Prior to fermentation, the specific gravity will be greater than 1, due to all the sugar dissolved in the water. After fermentation; the gravity will have dropped (due to the yeast converting sugars into alcohol) and you use the amount of that drop to calculate your %ABV.

Your analysis of fermentation put a whole new light on how much chemistry goes on in my hobby. Thanks for all you do!

so this is very late to point out but still something that should be pointed out
in the video, he states that "the fact that some animals and microbes have found ways to break down cellulose"
this is technically not a correct statement. for example, cows cannot break down cellulose, but instead they, and the animals that eat only plants and use cellulose as a source of energy, have these microbes in their bodies to break down the cellulose for them.

simply meaning
from a biological standpoint, no mammal or other type of creature except microbes (and maybe without my knowledge some insects) can break down cellulose.

it isn't really an important point, and doesn't matter in the grand scheme of things here, especially with what he did, which, btw is amazing, but from a biological standpoint that was the only single point in the entire thing that he didn't correct himself that i found to be wrong. (By all means if you can correct me here and show me any studies or anything that proves me wrong then i would love that btw!!)

overall, amazing content, exciting experiment and chemistry on point!!

Quick note: the flammability of an ethanol-water solution starts at a 1:1 ratio. It’s why the proof scale was invented and why 100 proof is 50% alcohol by volume. Without proper testing methods, the only way to prove shipments of alcohol hadn’t been watered down was to set them on fire.

This is why most alcohols are sold at an ABV below 50%, typically 45% or lower. It’s simply safer to not distribute flammable concentrations of ethanol. It is also why most bottles of hard liquor have that plastic nozzle on the tip, called a flame choke, that is made to prevent burning alcohol from traveling back up into the bottle and making a Molotov cocktail. Even if an alcohol-water solution at room temperature burns of 50% burns at room temperature, lower ABV’s burn at higher temperatures.

My step-dad said that when making moonshine they would test the purity by tossing some in a ditch and lighting it on fire. If sparks flew or the flame crackled then there were a lot of really nasty things in it that would make you "sick as hell". He wasn't referring to just a bad hangover. Considering some really sketchy ways some folks used to make liquor, this was apparently an easy test for those in the know to figure out the quality of the product. Incidentally, he was from a hillbilly family and they moved from the mountains of Appalachia when he was very young. His father woke up the family in the middle of the night and they left with just what they could carry and never went back. His dad was a shine runner and we think he got into some major trouble. The sweet smell from the toilet paper after the boil was from Vanillin a lot of trees and plants produce this phenolic compound. Vanilla beans are known to primarily produce this along with other phenolics which is what give natural vanilla it's distinct flavor. Whereas artificial vanilla uses vanillin as it's base and other artificial flavors to achieve a similar product

Moonshine should have absolutely no flavor at all. If it's cool enough that the alcohol isn't evaporating, it smells like water. The tell is when it hits the back of your throat, and it instantly liquifies the mucous back there and kills every germ in a two block radius. Then it slaps every nerve cell in your throat at the same time, just to let you know you're alive.
Yours was only ~120 proof though, so probably not THAT bad, really. I don't blame you for not slamming a whole shot of it at once, though.

FYI, it's those impurities that make it taste bitter that give people a hangover. A fair percent of those get carried straight to your bloodstream. Fastest way to fix that: Hypersaturate your body with water or orange juice in the morning. Lay down and wait for the water to flush out your kidneys. You'll get dizzy like you're drunk again almost immediately, but right after that the contaminints will become dilute and leave your bloodstream. Ibuprofen doesn't hust, but really it's just making you feel comfy, the water / juice is fixing the problem. :)

Hello, I realy like Your channel, lots of interesting experiments with approachable explenation.
As a Polish person an former biotech student I'd like to point few mistakes that You made (or rather impractical approaches).

Your destilation was so painfully "by the book" that it barely work.
Firstly, instead of steering it You should throw something that would provide spot for boiling to initiate (broken porcelain work great). By stearing you keep temperature of solution eaven, that why all of alcohol inside flask started to boil at once hence run away.
Secondly insulating column just kill it function, instead of having temperatures gradient that would allow water to condense on glass and drop back to boiling flask you created setup that used column as decoration.
Pro tip, by colecting multiple fraction you could save a lot of energy, time and just dont delute just purify product.
I also like to mention that ethanol is tasteless so thing that You tasted was a bunch impurities.
Ps. From my experience fermentation preformed on pure glucose still produced some methanol, although I judging it by compare density of 70°C - 75°C fraction with 78°C- 81°C (booth in temperature of -4°C) so I might be wrong. Remember tho that some of yeast used in process will die in process and be used as a source of substrates for rest of them.

Interesting, but Romanians nailed it in this case. We call it "Tuica de Pufoaica" wich means "Padded coat moonshine". You need a big very thick padded jacket, a long stick, an outhouse that has been used for some time and an alcohol boiler. You basically wrap the jacket around the stick, and dip it in the outhouse (feces ferment after some time and there is alcohol present), then after the jacket has been thoroughly wet, you put it in the alcohol boiler along some other things (usually fermented plums) and a lot of sugar (to cover the taste). Boil it at a very high temperature and the "moonshine" called "tuica de pufoaica" is ready. Enjoy.

To distill ethanol,  you bring your flask up to one degree below the boiling point of ethanol.  Let everything that is coming over finish.  Then throw it away.  Raise the temp to the exact boiling point of ethanol.  Collect your pure (as you can get) ethanol.  anything that is left  that takes more heat than the poiling point of ethanol,  is trash.  That's fractional distillation FYI.  Since ethanol loves absorbing water,  you can't distill it perfectly,  it absorbs atmospheric humidity.  There are chemical dryers  you can add to remove the water if you need purity.

Learn to make wine: To clear the solution add SO2 to kill the yeast that sinks down. and filter it out before destillation. Know, that the tthermometer tells you which substance is coming through. If you see the thermometer at 100°C, it is just water. So it should be much lower though near the boiling point of ethanol. If the temperature slowly increases then you are going up the boiling line. It means the solution will contain less and less ethanol. Something were we start to use fractional destiallation. Also know about azeotropic points that ethanol-water have at around 96% ethanol concentration. This means, you can never with water together get higher concentrations like that, if you not chemically or physically capture the water.
Learn about the kill of concentration of yeast by alcohold which is about 14%. So what you put in in sugar should not produce more than 14% ethanol, otherwise the reamining sugar remains in solution. Solution of polution is dillution.

What you are making is METHANOL, not ETHANOL. It is NOT moonshine. It is NOT safe for human or animal consumption. It is WOOD alcohol, not GRAIN alcohol. They are two different things. Methanol is POISONOUS ! See this site for more information, https://woodwoodland.com/wood-alcohol/ , but I quote from it:
You can not drink wood alcohol because it is poisonous.
Actually even seeing and smelling it will put yourself in danger too. Don’t assume it is just a cup of margarita since it is called wood alcohol.
If someone accidentally drinks wood alcohol, there will be serious consequences.
Wood alcohol will be metabolized to become formic acid and the toxin of formic acid will be harmful to the human body.
The acidosis caused by formic acid is severe and will lead to organ failure in the end.
Usually, damage caused by drinking wood alcohol includes:
Unconsciousness, headache, dizziness
Vomiting
Vision problems (blurred, tunnel, blindness)
Nerve damage
Heart and circulation problems
Liver damage
Kidney failure
So wood alcohol can be fatal alcohol if you do not treat it properly.

Additional thoughts: You need to watch Moonshiners before doing something like this. Those guys know A LOT more about the chemistry of distillation than you do. First off you let it run too long and likely had vinegar before you distilled it. There's an optimum period that mash "works off" before it goes too long and becomes vinegar. (happened to Josh on that show numerous times) 3 weeks was WAY too long to let the mash go. Also a hydrometer will tell you exactly what percentage of alcohol your mash is at post fermentation, and what percentage your alcohol is post distillation. You can also use it to tell how much sugar is in the mash as well. Each further distillation strips the impurities from the alcohol and raises the alcohol percentage but removes all flavor from it. Also wood alcohol is methanol not ethanol and methanol is toxic, let alone it's oxidized form.. formaldehyde.

Okay at the beginning of this before I watch the whole video I have to point out that yes ethanol is drinkable, but without impurities it 1) is incredibly dangerous to drink as the high level alcohol quickly becomes toxic by overwhelming your liver, and B) it won't taste good, it'll be like drinking rubbing alcohol. The flavor of alcohol is actually locked in the impurities that are transferred over during distilling from the mash. Most people consider 80 proof or 40% alcohol by volume to be the best drinking percentage for hard liquor. To make drinkable and palatable alcohol from something that doesn't inherently taste good, you'd need to add in flavors, one of the easiest ways to do that would be to add in terpenes from marijuana such as limonene. You could also add in CBD to give it some health benefits at the same time. Hey! There's a video you should do! You should do the chemicals of weed/hemp and extracting the oils and different components and flavors and see what you can make out of them!

I wonder if dehydrating the toilet paper after the washing process, then grinding it into a fine powder would've allowed the enzyme to work more efficiently.

You should have tried cold crashing the fermented product, at low temps (<40F) the yeast will tend to flocculate and drop out of suspension at which point you can siphon the product off of a rather condensed yeast/trub cake leaving that mess behind. From there you could try using other clarifiers like SiO2 (commercially called biofine) which is a, "vegan safe" clarifying agent. Other non vegan friendly options are Isinglass (collagen from fish bladders) or simple gelatin. Finally to address your foaming issues during boiling, it can be helpful to use something like a drop of simethicone, you can purchase that commercially as Gas-X an anti-flatulence product.

31:55 fellow distiller here. I was also amazed by how much you can get on my first batch years ago. I was also shoked to see how easy it is to turn fruits into alcohol. Like just grind it up, put it in water, eventually add sugar, throw in the yeast, wait and done. (If you want to have a wine or to not distillate you might want to follow a recipe).

Also, keep the head to light fires (methanol burns well). As for the tail (triethanol I think), I usually stop the distillation there and throw everything. Not worth the effort.

Conclusion : Being dangerous to make alcohol (people keeping the head, yikes), I understand why it's banned. Given how easy and cheap it is to make, I understand why some countries make it really hard to get a licence.

From the general knowledge I collected (never done it myself): you should always triple distill moonshine meant for human consumption due to it's source material containing quite a bit of methanol, and that methanol getting concentrated in with the ethanol. While other volatile substances are also a concern, you can taste those.

Also, as you mentioned with a big warning at the start, always check local laws considering home distillation. The exact laws vary by locality. Localities that do allow small amounts have a limit to quantity, and disallow for profit distilling. The exact definition of the later varies by locality too.

The waste product should be mostly lignin and it can still be used as a solid fuel for the still once dried.

Towards the end of the distillation of the 80 mls of ethanol, the final drops appeared oily, which means your tailings contained Fusel oils; German for "bad liquor". Russians have been home distilling vodka for generations & so it is customary to sprinkle ground black pepper onto the surface of each shot of vodka, which causes the Fusel oils to form an oily layer at the bottom of the glass. They drink down to that layer then stop & dump the Fusel oils.
However, after a few glasses drinkers become careless, which helps to explain why in 2014, the life expectancy for men in Russia was 64 years, placing it amongst the lowest 50 countries in the world in that category. I'm surprised you didn't taste the glucose before adding yeast to check for sweetness and do a hydrometer test before/after fermentation.

Unless I'm missing something, I think you're reading that hydrometer wrong. Hydrometers measure the specific gravity, aka density, not alcohol percentage directly. In order to determine alcohol content, normally you would measure the s.g. before and after fermentation, and based on how much it drops, you determine how much of the sugars have been converted to alcohol.
Some brewing hygrometers also have a scale for 'potential alcohol', which is the percentage of alcohol you could get from an unfermented solution if 100% of the sugars were fermented into alcohol- this number is highest before fermentation, and then you correct it by measuring again afterwards, and using the difference. If you're reading the PA scale after fermentation, it is NOT telling you the alcohol content. And if it's reading high (i.e. 80), that's a sign that you have mostly sugar, and a low alcohol content, not high.
Now maybe there's some sort of hydrometer with a scale I'm not familiar with, but I've never heard of a hydrometer with a scale for reading alcohol percentage directly, and I don't think that's even possible. It sounds like you're reading the PA scale as if it's a direct measure of alcohol content, which it absolutely is not.

Your fermentation would have been more efficient with two steps:

1. Supply the wort with nutrients...yeast like nutrients.
2. Aerate (oxygenate) the wort with an aquarium pump and stone. Yeast like a aerobic environment to get started. Once anaerobic they will start making CO2 and ethanol.

With these initial steps and temps between 25 and 30 C the fermentation time would have 3 to 5 days instead of two weeks.

the reason you had ""Puking" as distillers use it, is most probably because you put foil on the column. By doing that, you increased the vapor flow, but you also Stopped all chances of getting Reflux in the column. A "reflux still" is used to make High percent alcohols, but using your setup you could have easily made 40% alcohol. You added your first distillation back to the flask and added more solution to it, Instead you should have done added distilled water to Dilute the already distilled alcohol and Distil it again to get a cleaner higher percentage alcohol. But none the less great attempt :) don't drink it though as Methyl Alcohol would be in high quantity.

Biochemical process engineer here. I think this overall process is super interesting and this is a cool experiment, but I have some commentary I'd like to share.

Rather than using a chemical pretreatment, I believe you could also have finely ground the toilet paper in your buffer medium and the dissolved enzymes in one solution. To grind/chop the pulp, you'd use a high powered blender before enzymatic hydrolysis. So why use alkaline pretreatment at all? Well, the reference you use mentions alkaline pretreatment for "lignocellulosic" biomass, which is a key difference! Alkaline pretreatment for this feedstock functions to remove additional compounds the cellulose is entrained in, like lignin and hemicellulose. However, for high purity cellulose like in paper products, you simply need to increase the surface area of the cellulose before hydrolysis, since the cellulose is no longer entrained in cell walls with the other polymers like it is in raw biomass. I say this only because it might have saved you an extra step and wouldn't have taken as long as you might have believed if the paper was sufficiently ground before hydrolysis. Even though we know alkaline pretreatment works to increase the surface area of cellulose, it might not necessary because it requires an additional consumable and step in the process.

Some lignocellulosic pretreatment doesn't even use an alkaline pretreatment. Sulfuric acid pretreatment before hydrolysis and fermentation is also common, even if it functions completely differently than the alkaline pretreatment. In a perfect world, no pretreatment would be required to separate the cellulose from the biomass, but we've yet to figure out a way to do that. I would be happy to send you the papers that review these pretreatment steps if you're interested in this kind of work!

Not sure where you're located, but here in the US it is perfectly legal in all 50 states to make your own alcohol for personal use or to give away. However the distillation of home-brewed alcohols is illegal without a license. So if you ever want to do one of these projects and do a giveaway it has to be the alcohol produced from the initial Brew. Anything that you distilled would not only be illegal for personal consumption but also to sell or give away. Not to mention the process of distilling it in the first place is illegal without a license to do so.

Home mead maker here. I wish you had done a specific gravity measurement so we could have figured out roughly what the sugar content looked like. Heck. If I ever get bored, I might just redo this myself from a brewing perspective to see what the sugar content of your "mash" was. Judging by the amount of alcohol produced, it may not have been very high, but that could also have been a product of using brewer's yeast (which has a relatively low alcohol tolerance) versus something like EC-1119 that can ferment up to a 19% ABV (in ideal circumstances).

Also, most distillers would have called this first distillation a "stripping" distillation: a rough, quick and dirty, distillation just to decrease the total volume of your next distillation. Slower is usually better in distillation. Distillers will usually also take the "tails" (or the last bit of a distillation that doesn't exactly taste great after you get the "hearts" out) and add them into the next distillation they run.

The run is only coming out white because you had a bad case of the foamies due to overfilling it and probably too high of heat. If you poured some of the pot off, it would have prevented this, however cleaning the tube and column would have eliminated the white cloud you ended up with at the end.  Also, wood alcohol is product of the same type of fibers broken down, however methanol, or wood alcohol and other volatile compounds such as isopropyl are probably being output within the first good 10% of your batch that comes off at like 148 to 170. At 173 the ethyl alcohol is released and should be the only alcohol you do NOT discard. Once it gets to maybe 185 it may start to get cloudy again , so you should shut it down and discard the tails to eliminate fusil oils. You should have between 120 and 160 proof alcohol due to the use of the column as it tempers the distillation like a thumper would if you did it correctly without a paper enzyme bubble bath. The PH was probably not correct as well due to the enzyme remaining active while fermenting. The ph should be taken before yeast has been added and after fermentation so you could determine the ABV your wash will have. Once you know the percentage, then you have a good idea how much product it will make, and how much of the foreshots and heads you should remove.

I've done plenty of distillations in my time as a chemist, and I can tell you that filling your rbf almost to the top is a classic error. If you want the boiling to be stable, you want the largest possible area of interface between liquid and vapour above it, and with a spherical flask, that means filling it no more than halfway. Stirring also helps if you've got a heating mantle with a built in magnetic stirrer, but if not, use some anti-bumping granules, or just a few spoonfuls of rough gravel.

I'm also surprised that the initial enzyme treatment was done at such a high temperature: I always thought that the ideal temperature for enzymes to function was around body temperature, or 37 degrees C. Heating it up to 50 degrees C should have denatured the enzymes, though perhaps not enough to stop them working completely, hence why it still worked. But if you do this again, I would go to no more than 40 degrees C for the most efficient enzyme action.

It's not exactly true that methanol only occurs when fermenting certain types of food. You can make methanol from wood, in fact, that was the primary source of methanol for a long time. You just heat up the wood to 500°C (932°F), turning it into charcoal, catch the vapours and condense and distill them. That gets you methanol, as well as some acetone, acetic acid and methyl acetate.

As you get better at analytical chemistry it's extremely important to keep track of your dimensions (dimensional analysis). Chemists often use shortcuts with percent (%), which is a dimensionless number. However it's extremely extremely important to keep track of what we call the basis of how the percent was derived. Chemists have a nasty habit of dividing mass by volume or volume by mass and calling it a percent. It can only be a true percent if the units cancel.
So your hydrometer is most likely reporting the alcohol as volume / volume , 64% vol/vol, is equal to 50.5% ethanol, mass/mass. Additionally hydrometer's are very sensitive to temperature I believe you probably have error due to the hot liquid. That should help out your yield problem of expected mass. Moles per mole is also to be monitored very carefully during chemical reactions so you can calculate the expected mass.

When I worked in the lab, we would use two steel balls in our samples to masticate leaf tissue in tandem with enzymes and chloroform to break through cell walls and more to eventually get our DNA "pellets" from the inside of the leaves. We were testing for viruses running gels. The DNA of infected plants is quit different than that on non-infected plants, and their gels when running through electrophoresis would have one of several "extra" bands present, which indicated infection. I imagine the mastication method would simplify your process slightly in comparison to heating or in addition to.

Well, I mean, what did you expect from the taste test? It's just an ethanol solution without any aromatics added (apart from maybe some side products). This means that you essentially get something equivalent to vodka (I mean, let's be honest, noone cares about the taste of vodka) and leaves you with the same applications. So you could either use it in cocktails or make it the base for a liqueur, at least as far as food applications are concerned (well, or you could just drink it like that, but that's something you should do neither with Vodka or with Ethanol. Personally I'd argue the difference between alcohol as a food product with stimulating properties and alcohol as a hard drug is whether the only enjoyment you get out if it is the drunken stupor or if you do also enjoy the it's qualities as a flavour carrier).

The enzyme method was by far the right choice. After all this is exactly what malting does when making whiskeys. They sprout grains which allows the budding plant to create the enzyme that breaks down seed-starch into sugars. Its then baked at very controlled temperatures to kill the germs but preserve the enzyme, then its steeped into mash where the enzyme from the now dead buds now releases the sugars from the seed starches. Then the yeast is added.

some immutable rules when using quick fit glassware distillation apparatus : NEVER fill past half volume in your boiling flask, NEVER insulate a Vigreux column unless you know EXACTLY what you are doing, high boiling point liquids etc are dealt with by distilling at low pressure, with cloudy or particulates in a batch to be distilled, a pre filtration using something like Whatman medium grade qualitative filter paper on a Buchner funnel would help create a better product, and reduce foaming and frothing but may not obviate it, use a common alcohol hydrometer to test your distillate for alcohol content. Besides yeast strain type etc, Controlling fermentation temperature to the low side is a helpful way to reduce the amount of Fusel oil,  yeast metabolism by-products such as higher alcohols, aldehydes and ketones etc that are inevitably produced by yeast as the process continues. In any case, the worst portion and type of this Fusel oil fraction as it is called can and MUST be removed in any fermented and distilled alcohol intended for human consumption, the majority of these by-products have boiling points lower than ethanol,  B.P. ~78.6 Degrees Celsius, and thus will distill over first, this is usually accompanied by a smaller portion of the ethyl alcohol that is also discarded as the thermometer rises up-to distillation temperature , and controlled and stabilized near the B.P of the Alcohol, a little more of the distillate is also allowed to distill over just as a precaution to be certain that the Fusel oil has indeed been boiled off. This may sound like old hat to many of you, and it is, but it cannot be over-stated for the newbie who wants to give DIY booze a go. Every year many people either just flat out die or go blind, or at the least damage their Livers or worse Brains by drinking home made alcohol without getting rid of the first 100 Milli Liters or so that come from the condenser. Brain cells and the light sensitive cells on the Retina in the back of the eye are most sensitive to the livers metabolites of the Fusel oil , and to make matters worse, it can be a slow acting poisoning, often the damage is done by the next day, but this also offers a silver lining in that if caught early enough, the stomach can be pumped, activated charcoal used, or syrup of Ipecac to induce vomiting, a sulfur containing amino acid called cysteine, common in eggs, can also help prevent further liver damage. Ethanol itself, oddly enough, can also be given to protect the body from METHANOL poisoning, as it is preferentially acted on by the livers enzyme systems, while the methanol can be flushed out via the kidneys in urine, as the Methanol itself isn't terribly toxic, it's the metabolite of the methanol, which is Formaldehyde, that is highly toxic, because it is highly reactive, and binds irreversibly to any organic material having amino acids in it, so basically any part of your body. Formaldehyde is the main chemical in Formalin, which is Formaldehyde dissolved in ethanol, that is used to embalm body parts, seen some brain or eye in a jar at school ? that's the stuff it's stored in, oh, and another fun fact, because of this irreversible binding, it is also a potent carcinogen. Isn't it amazing the difference what one little carbon atom can make, between Methanol and Ethanol, either fun time at the Bar, or no fun at all at the Morgue. now where's my beer...

Homebrewer here, I notice you calculated ABV off of a single hydrometer reading.  This is not how hydrometers work, some hydrometers do have ABV markings on them (I use one myself) but those numbers are potential ABV based on the sugar in solution, not the amount of alcohol in solution.  In order to find out how much alcohol you generated with a hydrometer, you would have needed to take a specific gravity reading before adding yeast, and then again after fermentation. These numbers are your Original Gravity and Final Gravity respectively, you then Subtract the OG from the FG and multiply that number by 131.25 and that number is your ABV percentage.  Though this still doesn't help you after distilling, because you are changing the volume.  Calculating the ABV of a distilled spirit with a hydrometer really isn't possible, because you lose so much volume in the distillation process that your gravity readings will be thrown way off. You may have been able to use an alcoholmeter, but those are finicky, any sugars or other solubles still in solution will throw your readings way off. Really neat experiment though, I'm almost tempted to do it myself, but I think I'll just stick with brewing mead lol, waaaay simpler.

If you plan to drink the alcohol, please get rid of the first initial output as it contains methanol which will among other things, make you go blind. There was probably a few percentage points of Methanol in that jar he drank from at the end.

Take this video as a chemistry video. Not a brew video if that was not obvious.

Fungi release a bunch of stuff in their culture broth, mostly proteins including enzymes like the cellulase you used, and hydrophobins which are tensio-active proteins. They most likely caused your foaming problem while distilling. When the gas dissolved in the liquid is released (by the pressure drop when serving beer, or here by boiling it out) hydrophobins stabilize the bubbles and it starts foaming... it's actually a real issue in brewing, finding the right conditions for beer to form enough foam but not gush out of the bottle upon opening

Moonshine from toilet paper, what a bizarre but fascinating project :) Cool video. That said, I have a comment regarding Team Trees:

Team trees goal of 20 million trees is nice and all but it's so insignificantly small in scale that it will not make a dent in the co2 levels of Earth. In order to actually make a difference, humanity would need to plant 20 million trees every single day for years on end, and this assumes all the trees survive. And at that point they would store the co2 in their mass but that co2 would be released back into the atmosphere when the trees die and decay.

Team Trees goal is at best, a good intentioned jester that highlights communities who wish for a better future for the planet. And while this is a good thing, it is not realistic to expect a one off planting of 20 million trees to actually help the planet much. Real issue is the actual emission of co2 by humans and their constant use of fossil fuels, first that must be reduced and or eliminated and then humanity as a whole needs to unify in gradually removing the co2 from the atmosphere over a few centuries time

Nice project. Just on a side note for future endeavors, there is actually no point in covering the fractionating column with foil. Doing this prevents the actual fractioning from ocurring, as the whole column willeb at the same temperature as the flask and you will end up with a lot more water content than you would with an efficient fractionation process.

The distillation process will be slower this way, but you will get higher ethanol content in fewer runs.

ok they for this awesome content but i have to ask, why?

SOMEONE NEEDS A VACUUM FILTER!!!!!!!! (it would have made cleaning the toilet paper after being broken down by the base SOOOO much easier) - and of course - you would need at least a BIG one too lol - and those are not cheap - nono (BUUUUT, if you do what I did - it IS cheap hahaha - you have a professional glass blower make you one - and you show them the basic design - and then just tell them to make sure the bottom fitting is the same size - but the top part to be much bigger - and they will make one for you - you can even have them use the best kind of quality high temp glass if you want - which is needed since you want this to be very strong to withstand the high pressure of a good vacuum) lol - BUT holy shit THEY ARE SO WORTH IT - and I constantly use it when I work in my lab. I cannot imagine doing anything without it now! If you want to buy a SMALL receptacle (not even including the other required gear) - here is a piece made by Cole-Parmer lol: https://www.coleparmer.com/i/cole-parmer-vacuum-filtration-holder-membrane-size-90mm/0292330?PubID=UX&persist=true&ip=no&gclid=Cj0KCQiA5dPuBRCrARIsAJL7oejLOkFMwIYM-_kxAl2vrsbnpXtMXqFYwSx5XIznxMO0j1XiR5nUlIYaAm39EALw_wcB

Here is a setup that has the WHOLE kit and caboodle - if you're interested. YOU REALLY do need to get one of these. How can you be into chemistry and NOT have one of these yet?!?! THESE ARE LIKE FUNDAMENTAL TOOLS BUDDY!!! lol - new to chemistry much? https://www.sterlitech.com/botanical-extraction-filter-kit-90.html?wtx=GAW&gclid=Cj0KCQiA5dPuBRCrARIsAJL7oegXIh4rJChGmwsnxU3RaJdFTc9PTW_hiyBACzj33lOEW6N4dYvsIvYaAjdOEALw_wcB

Also - I can easily tell that you did not wash enough of the base out of the product - the coloring within was still rather apparent. I would have given the product at least 10-15 washes since this product is meant for consumption!!!! Trust me you do not want ANY of the base in your product before you proceed on to the next stage of your experiment. With a proper vacuum filter you could have done this easily. I would have ALSO put the product in a BLENDER with some distilled water after it was washed - and chopped up the paper even more! This would have also sped up the reaction process by quite a bit! Don't knock blenders lol - they work really well! ESPECIALLY if you have a Blendtec Blender like I do :D (will it blend? fuck yes it'll blend. It'll blend an entire fucking broom handle into dust if you want, FFS you can even blend a damn iphone in this behemoth of a blender LOL. That blender IS expensive though - and there is NO way around that cost if you want one - I too use the Blendtec Blender frequently in my lab LOL). I would have ALSO waited longer than 48 hours for the cellulase to finish up eating up the cellulose. I would have ALSO added more if it was required to finish off ALL of the product so you are left with a liquid with NO paper in it! This also means adding more of the citic acid etc. to even out the PH.

But buying bags of granulated sugar is probably cheaper. My understanding is you need some other things in there for normal yeast to function on sugar. I get 'yeast nutrient' myself. Honestly you are really lucky it didn't froth over in fermentation. Usually you have to leave a good amount of room for a froth that forms at the top. You probably got away with it because it didn't ferment properly for the reason I mentioned at the start. I make wine out of minute maid peach punch, granulated sugar, pureed boiled potatoes, yeast nutrient, and lalvin 1118. I add potatos to try to introduce these extra materials, but fear the starch is never converted into anything. You also have to keep adding sugar and nutrient as it goes along to up the alcohol  output as the ph keeps going more acidic and you would stall it initially otherwise.

Couple of things, if you clear the undistilled product with gelatin powder before distilling it you will get rid of most yeast particulate. Also i'd swap the pipes on your still so that the water circulator is vertical above the boiling water, you won't get that bubbly problem since it will cool it before that happens, and it will also, with a bit of tuning cause the alcohol to condense at the top of the still making for a more efficient process. Most moonshine stills are built this way.

If you use sulphuric/sulfuric acid to break down cellulose from wood pulp, then ferment it, that is the industrial process for manufacturing METHANOL not ETHANOL.  To clarify, that is not drinking alcohol, and can kill with as little as a few teaspoons, or cause blindness with as little as 1 teaspoon.  This has killed many moonshiners in the past.  Please post your process that you believe will make ethanol instead of methanol using wood pulp or paper or toilet paper, as I believe you have a misunderstanding.  Even small amounts of cellulose containing material, create a "head" of methanol that is usually decanted off when distilling the alcohol from the fermented mash.

making wood into sugar was a process used in germany in the early to mid thirties. i have a textbook from 1936 that describes the commercial process. sugar was an import commodity for germany back then and thru the treaty of versailles imports were severely restricted. sugarbeets became a viable crop option for northern tier countries to make their own sugar.


 also, there are several commercial variations of this process in use today where methanol and ethanol are won from wood fiber in a process called hydrolysis, where the wood fiber is broken down with the help of HCL and heat.

For anyone doing anything involving acid\base washes, please do not just wash until clear. An easy way to make sure you are removing unwanted contaminants is to take a ph reading pre base\acid wash and compare after rinsing. So lets say your toilet paper and water solution had a ph of 7.2, which was then dropped to 2.0 while treating with the base. To be relatively safe you should be washing and straining until you get back to that 7.2 pre treatment ph level.

Even with ale yeast (top fermenting, high temperature), you should have cooled your "wort" to about 25 degrees C. The yeast should also have been roused first. This is a very funny and interesting project! I would recommend boiling the liquid in the fermenting container prior to adding the yeast. This is an easy measure to control microbiology. A lactobacillus infection can produce all kinds of volatile components that, subjectively, can be labelled as "off flavours". Furthermore, in beer brewing, strict temperature control during fermentation is applied, again to minimize off flavours (diacetyl & aldehydes). Lastly, would you think you could also use this method to make grass moonshine? :)

0:44 You're showing alpha glucose. Cellulose is made of beta glucose, an anomer of the former. The inverted geometry at the 1' carbon is responsible for the properties of cellulose which differ from those of amylose (one of the key components of starch), which also has a 1-4 linkage producing a straight chain of glucose monomers.

Just a few thoughts from a home brewer perspective.
After fermentation is complete most people give the liquid a good stir to release all the trapped C02.
Next step is to let it clear which can take a week or 2 at room temp or a better way is to cold crash in a fridge which can take a few days,
this will separate the yeast as much as possible and give you a clear solution to distill, I would siphon this off top with a hose leaving the yeast at the bottom.
These steps I mentioned would have helped reduce the solution boiling over into the condenser.
Also another tip is to use little bit of butter in with your solution to break the surface tension to stop it boiling over.

Hi NileRed, I have some comments to improve the process (if you ever want to serve more toilet paper alcohol to your guests).
- You said that it is important to have an enzyme in a buffer and yet you rehydrated it in dH2O. What might have saved the day was starches and sugars acting as crowding reagents and prevented the denaturation of the enzyme
- If you want to know how much alcohol there is in your brew, just take a hydrometer for beer brewing and take the density before and after fermentation
- You were unsure whether the starch was fermented or not by the yeast: just take a small sample of your final product and add few drops of iodine. It turns dark blue/black when there is starch
- To avoid the mess during the first round of distillation, filter your brew and then degas it. The faster way would be to use a vacuum under stirring. Maybe a magnetic bar at the bottom of a Büchner flask coupled to a vacuum system. Alternatively, the CO2 is poorly soluble at "high temperature" and you could have warmed it up in your oven to 50 - 60C and stirred it heavily for some time to take out most of the CO2.

Have you ever heard about iron gall ink? It's the ink used in medieval period and beyond, made of oak gall and iron salts.
Making it from commercial chemicals should be quite easy, but doing it old fashion, starting from galls ( you can collect them yourself if you have some oaks around you ) it's quite less straight forward. There are a lot of ways to extract tannins and tannic acid from galls and they give different results in term of color.
I think it's could be fun even because there are lots of historic recipes and you can compare chemical knowledge in centuries.

I've tried it myself with good results and I've collected some documentation during the process so feel free to contact me in case.

My science expo project this year is doing the hydrolysis of cellulose chemically through a heterogeneous solid acid catalyst. The catalyst is then much easier to remove and reuse, especially when compared to liquid acid catalysts or enzymes. I love to see when biotechnology and chemistry are well explained and made simple!
Nevertheless, I want to point out that you could simplify the process by ignoring the pre-treatment step. It could be useful with journal or cardboard, due to the presence of lignin and hemicellulose. However, toilet paper is almost 100% cellulose and from my experience the endocellulases can easily deal with the internal bonds. Also, you made the right choice to use the enzymatic hydrolysis, I have already made acid hydrolysis and I can say that they are a pain in the ass.
BTW, an equally good and entertaining challenge could be to produce biodiesel from used coffee grounds ;)

One thing you can do to take down the water content and help filter off any residual solids is to run a quick freeze still on it. Pour your mixture into a plastic bottle, throw it in the freezer until it's solid and then invert it over another container. Let it drip for an hour, hour and a half, and you should be able to get most of the alcohol off while leaving at least a portion of the water behind.

When looking at hydrometers in glass containers, there is an optical illusion when it’s sitting on the bottom and it’ll look like it’s barely floating. The way to confirm is to gently tap the top of the hydrometer and feel if it taps the bottom of the container.

Cool idea using an enzyme to break down cellulose. I made a lot of crappy moonshine when I was in school, so I have some experience. I think you might find it goes faster if you don't overfill the boiling flask and if you connect the condenser directly to the flask instead of putting the reflex column between. Boil moderately first run, slower on second run. The first run should have had about the alcohol content you ended up with. The second run should have been strong enough that a sip would kill the top layer of skin in your mouth so it peels off after a minute or so. Except for the obvious foaming problem, I really don't see why it wasn't much stronger than it was. Also, unless the only goal is to see how much alcohol you can get out of it, don't bother with the heads and tails. The heads usually seem to result in a worse hangover (pectins or not) and the tails aren't worth bothering with. Maybe if you were distilling 100 year old French wine or something, but jailhouse toilet booze will rarely see an improvement in flavor.

@6:03 : There are actually different types of Cellulase enzymes, or, to be more precise, cellulase enzymes can do multiple things. They are grouped into endocellulases, which attack the bond at random positions, exocellulases, which "cut off" mostly cellobiose (the beta1-4 glucose disaccharide) from the ends of the bonds and cellobiases, which splits cellobiose into glucose. Most Bacteria and yeasts like T. reesei produce multiple exocellulases, endocellulases and cellobiases. Although the above isn't entirely correct since it was found out that most of the cellulases specify on one of these things, but most can actually do all of them, this classification is still common. Summarizing, cooking the cellulose in base definitely helps the process a lot, but I've also been able to produce significant amounts of glucose out of paper towels without any pretreatment except for cutting them down a bit and blending them with a household blender.
Edit:
Specifically t reesei doesn't produce a lot of enzymes that act as exocellulases, so they don't really attack the ends of the bonds too much - so while you can speed the process up alot by pretreatment, they can cope with pretty big chains - here is a figure showing what enzymes t reesei produces: ( https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Trichoderma-reesei-cellulolytic-enzymes_tbl1_317276203 )
